label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, March 1, 1948
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, describing the business affairs and successes of his Drink-O-Mat Corporation holdings in South Carolina and North Carolina.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his brother, Armant Legendre, describing the business affairs and successes of his Drink-O-Mat Corporation holdings in South Carolina and North Carolina.

metadata.label: Access Note

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
March 1, 1948
Mr. Armant Legendre
433 Gravier Street
New Orleans 12, La.
Dear Armant,
Just got back to the plantation after a trip
up to Boston to see about my Drink-O-Mat Machines.
They had been delaying shipping them with one ex-
oust after another so I thought I had better find
out what the trouble was and journey up there.
First I flew from here to Charlotte, North Carolina;
leaving the plantation at 3:30 in the morning after
getting to bed at 2. You can imagine my mental state
by the time I arrived in Charlotte and met the Fuher-
er and Sammie Trincher. We did theaters and Drink-
O-Mat all day. Fired everybody in the North Carolina
Corporation that had been employed there before and
hired an entirely new set of managers and office
force. Then Morris and I took the night train to
New York , rather Morris got off in Washington,and
I want on to New York, where I saw the head Drink-
O-Mat office. They had a lot of words for me but
no machines as far as I could see,so after doing
some business of my own I got on the night train to
Boston and went up there and went to the factory.
Of course, the New York Office had called the fac-
tory as soon as they found that I was really going
there, and everybody was in a sweat turning out our
machines and putting them in boxes saying that they
had all along been ready for us, but had just some
how delayed shipping them. I stayed there until
the machines were packed, and then took the night
train back again to New York. I ran around with
Patsy all day'and went to Janie's for dinner.that
night. This was certainly the most exhausting par
of the entire trip. Next day I did more work in
[End Page 1]
-2-
New York buying clothes for Gerry, and then took
the night train down to Charlotte. Met Sammie Trin-
cher in the morning, and we made a round of the mac-
hines that we had installed. They are doing very
well, and I watched one machine ring up 598 drinks.
There was a long line of people there waiting to dop
their nickels in. From there, I took the night train
to Charleston and crawled into bed about mid-night.
However, I read your letter before going ot bed and
certainly appreciate everything that you said. The
only thing that makes me mad is the social end of it.
If you had$100,000,000, you would not really like it.
You might like a "blow out" on Saturday nights, but 
nothing would ever make you want to go out every night
of the week and there is not the slightest reason in
the world why you should want to. I know I certainly
don't.
I will try and come down around April 20th, be-
cause as you say these are the times we have the most
fun. I have been ordered up to Washington for Navy 
duty on March 30th, but believe it only lasts for
two weeks, God Willing, and I might then be able to
go straight to New Orleans gathering up the Fuhrer
on the way. Will write you later about the whole mat-
ter as sign shows us what we're to do.
Love,
Sidney
[End Page 2]
